sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: Welcome to Unit 94 of our English learning journey. In this unit, we'll explore advanced elements of relative clauses, specifically focusing on the use of 'whose,' 'whom,' and 'where.'

sections.title: Definition
sections.content: These elements add depth and specificity to the information provided. Let's delve into the key concepts.

sections.title: 'Whose' for Possession
points: Understand the use of 'whose' to indicate possession in relative clauses.
The man whose car was stolen reported it to the police
The book, whose author is famous, has received critical acclaim

sections.title: 'Whom' as an Object Pronoun
sections.content: Explore the use of 'whom' as an object pronoun in defining relative clauses.
points: The woman whom I met at the conference is a renowned scientist
The student, whom the teacher praised, received an award

sections.title: 'Where' for Places
sections.content: Learn how to use 'where' in relative clauses to specify a location
points: The city where I was born is known for its rich history
The park, where we had our picnic, is beautiful

sections.title: Examples
sections.content: Let's examine examples to illustrate the application of relative clauses with 'whose,' 'whom,' and 'where'
points: The girl whose father is a doctor wants to become a nurse
The house where I grew up is now a museum
The teacher, whom the students admire, is retiring this year

sections.title: Usage and Content
sections.content: Understand the appropriate contexts for using 'whose,' 'whom,' and 'where' in relative clauses and how they contribute to the specificity of information.

sections.title: Recap and Summary:
sections.content: In summary, incorporating 'whose,' 'whom,' and 'where' in relative clauses enhances your ability to provide detailed and specific information.

sections.title: Additional Resources:
sections.content: For additional practice and reinforcement, consider exploring examples in language learning books and online exercises.

sections.title: Conclusion
sections.content: Thank you for joining today's lesson on 'Relative Clauses 3: Whose/Whom/Where.' Practice using these elements confidently in various situations, and feel free to reach out if you have any questions. Happy learning!
